title: About Jackson Ingvoldstad
text:
Jackson Ingvoldstad is a sports intern who joined 10/11 News in August of 2025.
He is currently a junior at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, where he is majoring in broadcasting media production and minoring in music technology. Being a student in UNL’s College of Journalism and Mass Communications, he has become involved in many different realms in the local broadcasting scene. He is a core member of UNL’s student-ran newscast, Nebraska Nightly. In 2025 he received a Gold Award from the Nebraska Broadcasters Association for Best News Feature. Jackson was also part of the Nebraska Nightly team (sports anchor) that won first place in television newscast (three days a week or less) in the Broadcast Education Association’s Festival of Media Arts.
In the spring of 2025, Jackson published his documentary Understaffed: Nebraska Prisons’ Mental Health Crisis as he was a part of UNL’s investigative in-depth reporting team. Jackson is also currently serving as Video Editor for the Daily Nebraskan (UNL’s independent student newspaper) where he is also the director of the DN’s live-music video series called Press Play, where local bands and artist visit the newsroom and perform concerts throughout the year.
On campus, Jackson keeps himself busy, currently serving as Treasurer and Awards Chairman for his fraternity, Phi Delta Theta, for which he also created a documentary-style piece that won the national Oxford Trophy award for the house in 2024. He is a part of the Order of Omega (a Greek leadership honor society), NHRI (a mentoring program where college students teach leadership skills to highschoolers), the Honors Program, the Open Lens Club.
Jackson is from Omaha, Nebraska and he is a fan of anything Nebraska to the core. In his free time he loves to play guitar with his friends and family, write music, and play tennis.

title: The Worst of the Best: NBA Hall of Famers’ Worst Games
text:
LeBron James made history. On December 4, 2025, James scored 9 points against the Toronto Raptors. For the first time since January 6, 2007 (1,297 games ago, during a time when a young senator from Illinois named Barack Obama was running for his first term as President), James was in the single digits for points scored in a game. The children of the LeBron Era (otherwise known as the 21st century) have been able to witness consistency in its greatest form; however, it seems as though the ride is coming to an inevitable end. James will be inducted into the Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame in the near future. While James has been soaring high for as long as many can remember, several of his peers have swooped down to take a break and lay an egg.
To determine who’s been flying and who’s been laying eggs, John Hollinger’s Game Score efficiently measures a player’s performance in a single game.
Game Score = (PTS+(0.4FGM) - (0.7FGA - 0.4FTA) + (0.7OREB+(0.3DREB) + STL + (0.7AST) + (0.7BLK) - (0.4PF) - TO))
A Game Score of 20 is pretty good. A Game Score of 40 and up is remarkably amazing. A Game Score in the negatives… that is a bad performance.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(hoopR)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)
library(waffle)
library(gt)
library(patchwork)
library(rvest)
library(janitor)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(ggrepel)

nba <- read_csv("nba.csv")

decadestars <-nba |>
     mutate(
       EFF = (points + rebounds + assists + steals + blocks) - (field_goals_attempted - field_goals_made) - (free_throws_attempted - free_throws_made) - turnovers,
       TS = (points/(2*(field_goals_attempted + (.44*free_throws_attempted)) )),
       GS = (points+(0.4*field_goals_made) - (0.7*field_goals_attempted) - 0.4*free_throws_attempted) + (0.7*offensive_rebounds+(0.3*defensive_rebounds) + steals + (0.7*assists) + (0.7*blocks) - (0.4*fouls) - turnovers))|>
  filter(athlete_display_name == "James Harden" | athlete_display_name == "Carmelo Anthony" | athlete_display_name == "LeBron James" | athlete_display_name == "Kevin Durant" | athlete_display_name == "Chris Paul" | athlete_display_name == "Damien Lillard" | athlete_display_name == "Russell Westbrook" | athlete_display_name == "Luka Doncic" | athlete_display_name == "Kyrie Irving" | athlete_display_name == "Stephen Curry" | athlete_display_name == "Nikola Jokic" | athlete_display_name == "Giannis Antetokounmpo" | athlete_display_name == "Kawhi Leonard" | athlete_display_name == "Dwyane Wade" | athlete_display_name == "Kobe Bryant" | athlete_display_name == "Paul George" | athlete_display_name == "Jimmy Butler" | athlete_display_name == "Anthony Davis" | athlete_display_name == "Klay Thompson" | athlete_display_name == "Dirk Nowitzki" | athlete_display_name == "Rudy Gobert" | athlete_display_name == "Draymond Green")

badgs <- decadestars |>
  filter(minutes > 25)

worstgs <- badgs|>
  filter(GS <= -5)

worstestgs<- worstgs |>
  filter(GS <= -6.5)

dw <- worstgs|>
  filter(athlete_display_name == "Dwyane Wade")

ggplot() + 
  geom_quasirandom(
    data=badgs, 
    aes(x=minutes, y=GS), color="grey")+
  geom_quasirandom(
    data=worstgs, 
    aes(x=minutes, y=GS), color="red")+
    annotate("rect", fill = "blue", alpha = 0.1, 
        xmin = -Inf, xmax = Inf,
        ymin = -Inf, ymax = -5) +
  geom_text(aes(x=55, y=-8, label="Astonishingly bad game zone"), size=3.5)+
theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title="First-Ballot NBA Hall of Famers Bungle Here and There",
    subtitle = "Low Game Scores means the player peformed badly.",
    caption = "Source: HoopR | By: Jackson Ingvoldstad",
    x = "Minutes Played",
    y = "Game Score"
    ) + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 11), 
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )









Nobody is perfect, and it’s nice to remember that when comparing one’s own success to that of LeBron James. In fact, many future NBA Hall of Famers have been FAR from it in their past.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=worstgs, 
    aes(x=minutes, y=GS), size = 3, color="red")+
   geom_quasirandom(
    data=dw, 
    aes(x=minutes, y=GS), size = 3, color="orange")+
   geom_text_repel(
    data=worstestgs, 
    aes(x=minutes, y=GS, label=PlayerTeamSeason)) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title="A Handful of Abissmal Games Stand Out",
    subtitle = "Dwyane Wade achieves the most worst games (marked in orange).",
    caption = "Source: HoopR | By: Jackson Ingvoldstad",
    x = "Minutes Played",
    y = "Game Score"
    ) + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 11), 
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )









James’s right-hand man from Miami (and for an odd point in time, Cleveland) has accumulated the most of these truly awful games. Dwyane Wade terrified Miami Heat nation on April 24, 2004, when, in a first-round playoff game against the New Orleans Hornets, Wade scored 2 points, went 1-8 from the field, and had 6 turnovers. The Heat lost the game 77-71, but managed to pull through and knock the Hornets out of the playoff pictures through the successes of Caron Butler, Eddie Jones, and Lamar Odom. Wade’s shameful performance was soon shrugged off when, three days later, another member of the banana boat crew joined him in terrible post-play.
On April 27, 2004, Carmelo Anthony and the Denver Nuggets faced off against Kevin Garnett’s Minnesota Timberwolves in the playoffs. Anthony did not come ready to play, scoring 2 points, shooting 1-16 from the field, with 4 turnovers. Unlike Wade’s Heat, Anthony’s Nuggets could not persevere through Anthony’s struggles and were knocked out of the playoffs that round.


Code
worstestgs |>
  select(PlayerTeamSeason, points, field_goals_made, field_goals_attempted, turnovers, team_winner) |>
  top_n(10, wt=field_goals_attempted) |>
  mutate(
    team_winner = case_when(
      team_winner == TRUE ~ "Win",
      team_winner == FALSE ~ "Loss"
    )
  ) |> 
  arrange(desc(field_goals_attempted))|>
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    points = "Points",
    field_goals_made = "Shots Made",
    field_goals_attempted = "Shots Attempted",
    turnovers = "Turnovers",
    team_winner = "Win or Loss"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "The Postseason Was Not the Time for Players to Stink It Up",
    subtitle = "*Highlighted games were in or for the playoffs."
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("Data as of Dec. 05 **By:** Jackson Ingvoldstad  |  **Source:** HoopR")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )
   ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "lightblue"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = PlayerTeamSeason == "Carmelo Anthony, Nuggets 2004")
  ) |>
   tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "darkred"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = PlayerTeamSeason == "Dwyane Wade, Heat 2004")
  ) |>
   tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "gold"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = PlayerTeamSeason == "Klay Thompson, Warriors 2024")
  )

Among the terrible post-play, Klay Thompson joins Anthony and Wade, who in recent history went 0-10 in an elimination game against the Sacramento Kings. It was Thompson’s last game with the Golden State Warriors. After the 2024 season ended, he was traded to the Dallas Mavericks.
Although James decided to finally join his peers and lay low in scoring for the week, his consistency still reigns superior, as in the realm of Game Score, he is not featured once as “Astonishingly bad game zone”. James’ consistency is one we cannot deny.
